boardgame.name: Dollar Bill Poker
boardgame.description:
Dollar Bill Poker - An inset on the box lid shows Tony Randall and Jack Klugman endorsing the game.

Dollar Bill Poker (a game of bluff and challenge) is similar to "Liar's Dice" using a special deck of numbered cards instead of dice. There are six cards of each number 1 through 6 and six "Wild Cards". Everyone (from two to six players) starts with a handful of dime-sized cardboard discs, each of their own color. A special green playing mat is placed in the center of the playing area. It contains places for cards and a grid for the betting discs. The dealer deals out a predetermined number of cards depending on the number of players, and each player lays three cards in the "Down" space in front of him on the game mat.

The first player will add a card to their "Down" stack and place a bid of at least two of any number one through six by putting a disc on the grid in the proper row and column to indicate their bid. In turn around the board, each player must make a higher bid or challenge the bid just made. The bids reflect the combined total number of cards in everyone's "Down" stack having the same number on the card as the bid (including "Wild Cards"). For example: a bid of 4 fives, means that a player thinks there are at least 4 cards containing the number five (or "wild") in the collective total of everyone's "Down" stack. Players may bluff in their bidding in an effort to outwit the other players.

When a challenge occurs, the other players (in turn) get to place a higher bid or allow the challenging player go through with the challenge. If no higher bids are placed, the cards from everyone's "Down" stack are revealed to see if the bid was successful or not. Standard poker chips are used to keep score. The winner is the player with the most chips after the predetermined number of rounds have been played or some other end-game condition occurs. (The rules are inconclusive on how to end the game, but a predetermined number of rounds seems to be the direction intended by the game designers.)

Game contains 4 pagodas and 16 puzzle pieces, along with a spinner. To start, all puzzle pieces are placed face down in the center and each player takes one pagoda.

If the upturned piece matches the player's pagoda color, they keep it. If not, it is shown to all players and returned to the center, white or black side up. If the spinner lands on Mushu, the player must trade their pagoda with another player. First player to complete their pagoda with all 4 pieces wins.

The elf is only worth 4 points at the end of the game while the dwarf is worth 6.

boardgame.name: Party Medley
boardgame.description:
Party game. There are card slips (like tickets in size). One slip will have a word on it. Its matching slip will have another word but related to the first slip word. For example, a first-half slip might have the word 'Buckingham' and its other half would be the word 'Palace'.

The second half slips are placed around the house. Each player is given a first half slip with the word that will match one of the slips around the house. At the word "Go", the players set off to look for their match. If a player thinks he has found it, he takes both slips back to the host and, if correct, earns one point. Then he is given another slip to solve. After the host calls time, the player with the most points, wins.

boardgame.name: Underwood
Ундервуд
boardgame.description:
The game “Underwood” reminds you of a simple card game based on its game mechanic but the actual point of it is to form words using letters, sort of like “Scrabble”. “Underwood” has a much more “intellectual-educational tint” compared to normal card games and a much more dynamic gameplay than “Scrabble”: words are easier to form, there are more unexpected events in the game and a lot less stress.

At the beginning of the game each player receives 7 cards. The deck is placed on the table, one card is drawn and placed next to it, this will be the beginning of the “tape”. Players then take turns.

A players turn consist of:
• Draw three cards from the deck,
• If possible form a word using the cards from your hand and placing it before you,
• Place one of his remaining cards to the “tape”.

Each player during his turn adds one card to the “tape”, this way the “tape” becomes longer. If a player needs a certain letter to form a word but doesn’t have them he can take them from the “tape”, he also takes the remaining letters following the one he took.

The “Underwood” card — a free card. Can replace any letter in played word. You can take the “Underwood” card used by another player by replacing it with the letter it was used as. “Underwood” cannot be placed on the “tape”.

Prize cards can be played together with a word if the word fits the cards criteria (for example, is a piece of clothing, none of the letters repeat). The prize card increases the points for that word and can give a player some extra possibilities.

When a player “leaves” (has no cards left to play at the end of his turn or only has prize cards), the round ends and points are counted. Points for a players word are calculated based on the letter cost of that word (each letter is worth a certain amount of points) and prize card used. The cost of letters that remain on the players hands is deducted from his point total. It is possible to get a negative result due to this.

Points earned during a round sum up with points gained on previous rounds. The game is played until one player earns the necessary amount of points to win (the amount of points should be decided before starting the game). The first one to earn them is the winner.

This game contains:
• 102 letter-cards;
• 14 prize cards;
• 4 “Underwood” cards;
• Game rules.

More about cards
A letter card, apart from the letter also has its cost shown (how points a player gains from using it in his word) and the number of cards in the deck with this letter.

A prize card has: an icon, conditions to play this card and the prize that it gives. The icon shows what the card requirements are. There is also a more detailed explanation on what needs to be done.

boardgame.description:
The city of Whitewater has suffered a great tragedy; for reasons unknown the dead have risen up from their graves and seek to feed upon the living. The city became overrun in a single night and the few remaining survivors now scavenge to survive during the day and barricade themselves safely away at night.

However, things would be easier if other groups of scavengers were not also competing for the same resources as you!

boardgame.name: Wild West Shooting Gallery
boardgame.description:
A target shooting game with some humour. Just look at the outlaw target, shooting his own foot.

Here are the complete rules:

WILD WEST SHOOTING GALLERY
Here we have four lawless characters from way out in the Wild West, at present in a gay mood. Little do they know that the Sheriff’s posse is hot on their trail.
Why not join the Sheriff and his men and try your skill at shooting these rascals down?
HOW TO PLAY
Stand the target in the slotted wooden blocks at the sides of the box, then place it at a distance of four to five feet from the players.
Hold gun in your right hand and insert the metal end of the dart into the muzzle, resting rubber head of dart against palm of left hand, press home dart until spring “clicks" into loaded position.
Play can be for a pre-arranged total score, the first player reaching such score being the winner, or for a certain number of rounds, the highest scorer being the winner, 2nd and 3rd highest runners-up.

In Mindstein, each player takes a turn as the reader, reading a card with five multiple choice questions. boardgame.name: Komm wir spielen Bauernhof
boardgame.description:
From the publishers description: Who wouldnt own a really nice farm. With cow and horse, tractor, house and barn etc. Everyone can win these in this game. Guessing and luck with the dice will lead to victory. Who first gets a farm by dice rolls wins.

It is a roll and move game. Twelve cards for each player are shuffled and put on the board. Clockwise the players roll and move their pawns according the die roll. Sometimes they get to take a card, sometimes they must get rid of a card, and sometimes they challenge the other player. Challenging means putting the die in one hand and then the player guesses which hand. Correct guesses give the player a card, false guesses make him lose a card. The first player to have 7 (out of 12 per player) cards has a full farm and wins.
